text.147_Daf, 0_Line, 0_Comment: Mishnah. A vat [for wine-pressing] made of stone that a heathen [sealed with] tar: it was customary to lift a small amount of wine into it [i.e. the vat] to overcome the smell of the tar.
text.147_Daf, 0_Line, 1_Comment: To scour it: [This is] explained in the gemara [as scouring using] water and ashes.
text.147_Daf, 8_Line, 0_Comment: He taught the customary case: because it is the custom of the tar-sealers to throw wine into it [i.e. the vat].
text.147_Daf, 3_Line, 0_Comment: And of earthenware, even if the tar is peeled off, it is forbidden: one might think every opinion holds this way since earthenware itself without tar absorbs wine.
text.147_Daf, 1_Line, 0_Comment: Of wood: which requires more tar since it absorbs more wine [i.e. than a stone vat]. Rabbi says scour it as with the stone [vat] and the Sages disagree.
text.147_Daf, 5_Line, 0_Comment: Gemara. But if he trampled [grapes] in it [i.e. the vat]: without tarring, scouring is not necessary, rather rinsing [is sufficient].
text.147_Daf, 9_Line, 0_Comment: Others say, Raba says only when tarred: [if the vat is tarred, but] he did not trample [grapes] in it, this is the case in which scouring is sufficient.
